content: @WG-async-foundations time for our meeting

We closed one issue last week:

  • Suggest async {} for async || {} #76011
Any other updates?
Not sure if @Nell Shamrell-Harrington is here, but I saw some movement on the Stream RFC
Yeah, just signal boosting the discussions around "driving futures to completion" thread.
There's a lot of bikeshedding happening over the name for the #[must_not_await] RFC (is that even it's name now?).

tmandry said:

Not sure if Nell Shamrell-Harrington is here, but I saw some movement on the Stream RFC

Specifically, the next method was removed so it can move forward

I sent out a pre-rfc to rust internals https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/pre-rfc-leave-auto-trait-for-reliable-destruction/13825
It would be helpful to get more of the async perspective considered, for anyone who's interested.
Okay thanks for the updates, I think we can move on
Might do a collaborative summary docs on the different proposals in the future. Just wanted to first get that out.
2 new issues to triage
Regression: missing MIR for generic async fn across crates #81000
Possibly fixed already, looks like
with a test
closing
ICE in github build #80998
this may be a dupe of the first one
probably not actually
also has a PR!
ah yeah, that's the one I need to review =)
okay, that's all!
Any other updates / comments / topics for discussion?

As far as the RFC for the #[must_not_await] lint goes, I think we need to move the discussion towards the actual lint instead of the name. We need to finalize on a name and move forward, since imo, there's other topics which are of a higher priority to discuss.
+1, bikeshedding names seems unproductive.

I think the documentation around the feature should help explain it to users. I understand why the name is a such a big topic for debate, given the complex nature of the ideas it is working with, but better documentation should alleviate some of the pain with whatever name we choose, since none of them really give the whole picture.
Names cannot always be completely self explanatory, the important thing is their function is documented. Imo.
My read is that everyone is okay with the lint, and the name is the last thing to discuss

Didrik Nordstrom said:

Names cannot always be completely self explanatory, the important thing is their function is documented. Imo.

I agree, but think the name can still be better in this case
and multiple people commented saying the name confused them in the same way

My read is that everyone is okay with the lint, and the name is the last thing to discuss

I can see that, but how can we get consensus on a name? A survey possibly?
What are the options?
The most popular option seems to be #[must_drop_before_suspend], the only problem with this being it's wordy.
There are two ways I know of.. either drive consensus in the RFC, or state in the RFC that the name is provisional and will need to be revisited before stabilization
There's also #[must_not_suspend] which was suggested at different points through the discussion.
no_suspend.. the possibilities are endless!
Ideally, I'd like to resolve this sooner rather than later, since the same points might be brought up again at a later date.

no_suspend.. the possibilities are endless!

I mean, as the saying goes, "There are two hard problems in CS.."
(following no_mangle etc)
Well.. I kind of like #[must_not_suspend]
it retains similarity to #[must_use]
while seeming more "correct" to me than #[must_not_await]
or at least harder to misinterpret

1. Race conditions
  2. Naming things
  3. Off by one errors

Didrik Nordstrom said:

  1. Race conditions
  2. Naming things
  3. Off by one errors

Lol, markdown injected the WRONG numbers. Didn't allow me to write out-of-order

Yes, that's my personal choice as well, as it's concise and as @tmandry mentioned, is reminiscent of #[must_use] making things consistent. Plus, it also alludes to suspension of tasks. Any further information about the behavior of the lint should be answered via documentation.
I recommend advocating for that then, and not trying to convince everyone that it's the best option, but an acceptable one
I think the lint error text is going to be more important to users.
^ it depends on which users, though
there are people who will see the lint, and people who will just read the code
though I guess if the lint text is embedded in the attribute, that would make it more self-explanatory
anyway
Users of a must_.. type as defined by a 3p library I imagine is the most common.

I think the lint error text is going to be more important to users.

That's a great point as well. The warning text should also include relevant information and a link to the documentation.
I think it's important that a name isn't easily misinterpreted to mean something different than it means
and less important that it's obvious on first reading what it means
which is a subtle point
Why suspend over await btw? More general?
But to conclude, I will advocate for #[must_not_suspend] as the an acceptable option and bring up all the points raised here, and see if that will help resolve that discussion.
like, if you know you don't know what something means, that's better than thinking you know but not knowing :)

Didrik Nordstrom said:

Why suspend over await btw? More general?

must_not_await was interpreted as meaning "you can't .await this type"
when it really means "you shouldn't have a value of this type laying around when you suspend, aka await something"
the naming will work for generators too, if we stabilize those, which is nice
Awesome, thanks for the input @tmandry @Didrik Nordstrom I'm going to leave a comment on the PR before the end of the day today.
sounds good!
great!
3 minutes left. Any remaining topics?
If not, thanks for coming and I hope you have a great day :wave:
